senses.de: A positive declaration to give confidence
senses.ex: He gave her an assurance that he would be there on time

Tips.title: Reassurance
Tips.description: Used when someone needs to be comforted or convinced about something.
Tips.example: His mother's assurance calmed him before the exam.

Tips.title: Commitment Indication
Tips.description: Indicates a strong commitment to act or support.
Tips.example: Her assurance of help made me feel supported.

Tips.title: Strengthens Promises
Tips.description: Often used to emphasize that a promise is solid and reliable.
Tips.example: I need your assurance that you will deliver the project on time.

senses.de: Confidence or certainty in one's abilities

Tips.title: Self-Confidence
Tips.description: Refers to being secure in oneself, without sounding arrogant.
Tips.example: Her assurance impressed the interview panel.

Tips.title: Perceived Competence
Tips.description: Demonstrates capability and can make others more trusting of one's abilities.
Tips.example: He handled the situation with assurance, showing his expertise.

Tips.title: Positive Connotation
Tips.description: Carries a positive tone, indicating reliability and trustworthiness.
Tips.example: Speaking with assurance can make your arguments more persuasive.

senses.de: A policy sold by an insurance company
senses.ex: He took out an assurance for his new car

Tips.title: Financial Security
Tips.description: Used in the context of providing protection against financial loss.
Tips.example: The businessman took assurance against fire damage to his stores.

Tips.title: Insurance Specific
Tips.description: Specific to the insurance industry and might not be interchangeable with 'insurance'.
Tips.example: Her life assurance policy ensured her family's financial stability.

Tips.title: Long-Term Planning
Tips.description: Often associated with long-term commitments or plans, like life assurance.
Tips.example: Assurance policies are crucial for long-term financial planning.

Certificate.wordDefinition:
A certificate is a document that serves as proof that you have completed a course or achieved a certain level of proficiency.

It is applicable in education or professional settings, where certificates are awarded after completing a qualification or training program.

Assurance guarantees something to be true or reliable while a certificate serves as proof of completing a course or achieving a certain level of proficiency.

Confidence.wordDefinition:
Assurance is a stronger word than confidence. It means having a guarantee or a promise that something will definitely happen or be provided.

Confidence is a feeling of trust in your own abilities, judgement, or knowledge. For example, if you are confident that you know the answer to a question on a test, it means you believe that you are right and you have faith in your own abilities to answer correctly.

So assurance is about having a promise or a guarantee that something will happen, while confidence is about having trust in your own abilities.

Conviction.wordDefinition:
Assurance and conviction are both words that express confidence or belief in something, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Conviction refers to a strong belief in something, often coupled with a sense of determination or passion. For example, someone might say "I have a conviction that everyone should be treated equally," meaning that they strongly believe in that principle and may take action to ensure that it is upheld.

Assurance is more about having confidence or certainty, while conviction is about having a strong belief or sense of purpose.

Guarantee.wordDefinition:
Assurance and guarantee may seem similar, but they have differences in their meanings. Assurance means to give someone confidence or a promise that something will happen, but it's not always guaranteed.

For example, a doctor can give a patient assurance that their medicine will cure them, but there is no guarantee because everyone's body reacts differently.

A guarantee is a promise or an agreement made by someone to ensure that something will happen or be done. It is a legal term that has a specific implication that if something doesn't happen, the person who made the guarantee will provide compensation or take responsibility for the mistake.

For example, when you purchase an electronic device, the manufacturer provides a guarantee that it will work for a certain duration, and if it doesn't, they will replace it or refund your money.

Assurance is a promise that gives confidence, and a guarantee is a promise that provides a legally binding obligation to do something or provide compensation if it doesn't work.

Pledge.wordDefinition:
Pledge means a promise or commitment to do something. For example, a student might pledge to study harder to improve their grades.

Both assurance and pledge involve a level of commitment, but assurance is more about a sense of security and confidence in the future, while pledge is more about a specific promise or commitment to take action.

Assurance is often used in business or personal relationships where trust is important, while pledge is often used in personal or social contexts where promises are made.

Promise.wordDefinition:
Promise is when one person gives their word to another person that they will do something. For example, if a parent promises their child that they will take them to the zoo on the weekend, they have made a promise to their child.

Assurance gives you confidence and promises are commitments made by one person to another.

Security.wordDefinition:
Assurance refers to the confidence or certainty one has about something, while security refers to protection or safety from harm or danger.

If you install a security camera at your front door, it will protect your home from potential burglars.

Assurance is more applicable to situations where you need trust or confidence in someone or something, while security is more applicable to situations where you need protection from harm.

Surety.wordDefinition:
The words assurance and surety both mean confidence or certainty, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Surety is often used in relation to a guarantee of payment or responsibility. For example, if someone acts as surety for a loan, it means they are guaranteeing that they will pay the loan if the original borrower cannot.

Assurance is used when talking about promises or guarantees related to a particular thing happening, while surety is used when talking about someone taking responsibility for another person's obligation or debt.

quotes.Text: It is quite amazing how hard the subconscious works when it is made to understand that this life is not a rehearsal, there is no safety net and no assurance of any final closure. It is also quite appalling to realize how catatonic the imagination can become when we hedge our bets, opt for the safer direction at every fork in the path.
quotes.Title: British Novelist
quotes.Name: John Burdett

quotes.Text: The essence of democracy is its assurance that every human being should so respect himself and should be so respected in his own personality that he should have opportunity equal to that of every other human being to show what he was meant to become.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Anna Garlin Spencer

quotes.Text: The characteristic of the hour is that the commonplace mind, knowing itself to be commonplace, has the assurance to proclaim the rights of the commonplace and to impose them wherever it will.
quotes.Title: Spanish Philosopher
quotes.Name: Jose Ortega y Gasset

quotes.Text: By liberty I mean the assurance that every man shall be protected in doing what he believes is his duty against the influence of authority and majorities, custom and opinion.
quotes.Title: English Historian
quotes.Name: John Dalberg-Acton

quotes.Text: There can be no great courage where there is no confidence or assurance, and half the battle is in the conviction that we can do what we undertake.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Orison Swett Marden

quotes.Text: The poet exposes himself to the risk. All that has been said about poetry, all that he has learned about poetry, is only a partial assurance.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: A. R. Ammons

quotes.Text: Everybody in the real world will agree - the moment a project is behind deadline, quality assurance tends to go out the window.
quotes.Title: Welsh Inventor
quotes.Name: Alan Cox

quotes.Text: However, there is no assurance that we can produce world class players so soon. Only time can tell.
quotes.Title: Pakistani Athlete
quotes.Name: Jahangir Khan

quotes.Text: It may be said with a degree of assurance that not everything that meets the eye is as it appears.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Rod Serling

quotes.Text: People want to have some assurance that their privacy, their data is going to be protected.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Ro Khanna
